critique: This executive order, issued by George Bush in 1993, imposes further sanctions on the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (Serbia and Montenegro) due to actions and policies deemed a national emergency. It prohibits certain transactions related to transshipment and vessels associated with the country. The order invokes the International Emergency Economic Powers Act and the United Nations Participation Act, granting the Secretary of the Treasury broad authority to implement these sanctions. The order does not directly address immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. It focuses on economic and foreign policy measures. The order expands executive power by invoking emergency powers and delegating authority to the Secretary of the Treasury. It also centralizes control at the federal level. There is no direct ideological tilt evident in the document itself, as it is primarily a foreign policy action. The order does not directly regulate the economy beyond the specific sanctions imposed on Yugoslavia.
